isis.stitle: CF 500, CF 600 - Electrical - Exterior Lighting - General Procedures - Headlamp Aim Adjustment

step1.para: Place the vehicle with the following conditions:

step2.para: The area around the headlamps is not deformed.
The unloaded vehicle is parked on a flat level surface.
Tire inflation pressure is at the specified value.
The vehicle is in a state ready for driving (with a full tank of fuel, oil level and coolant).
The vehicle has been bounced several times.
Prepare a thick white paper.
Stand the paper perpendicular to the ground at a position 3 m (9.84 ft) away from the headlamps.
Ensure that the centerline of the vehicle is perpendicular to the paper face.

Draw a horizontal line (H line) on the paper, showing where the headlamps should strike (at the same height from ground as the headlamp bulb center, which is marked on the headlamp lens by a 2 mm by 2 mm square).
Draw a horizontal line (H LH and H RH lines) parallel to the H line but 20.9 mm (0.82 in) below it.
Take appropriate measures to prevent any influence of other lights.
Start the engine.
Turn the LOW beam headlamps ON.

On the paper, observe the portion of the light pattern that has a distinctly higher area of intensity. Check that the top edge of this high intensity area is at the H RH/H LH reference line and below the cross-hatched area as shown in the illustration below.
If not, adjust the lights in the vertical direction.

caution.para: Both the inboard and outboard vertical aim screws must be turned the same amount in the same direction. Do NOT turn the screws different amounts or in different directions.

note.para: Do not finish the aiming procedure by turning the screws in the counterclockwise screwdriver direction. If you are adjusting in the counterclockwise screwdriver direction, overshoot the adjustment by one full turn and then turn the screwdriver clockwise one full turn, so you finish the adjustment in the clockwise direction and still line up with the vertical aiming line. This applies to both screws.

step2.para: Use a #2 Phillips screwdriver with at least a 150 mm (6 in) long shaft.
Insert the screwdriver in the inboard aiming hole until it engages the gear at the back of the headlamp. ALWAYS start with the inboard aiming screw as it is the primary vertical aiming screw.

Turn the screwdriver in the counterclockwise direction to move the headlamp aim upward or in the clockwise direction to move the headlamp aim downward, WHILE COUNTING THE NUMBER OF TURNS MADE. Continue turning this screw until the vertical aim is properly adjusted, but make sure you finish in the clockwise screwdriver direction. If you are adjusting in the counterclockwise screwdriver direction, overshoot the adjustment by one full turn and then turn it clockwise one full turn, so you finish the adjustment in the clockwise direction and still line up with the vertical aiming line.
Then insert the screwdriver in the outboard aiming hole until it engages the gear at the back of the headlamp.

Turn the screwdriver the same number of turns in the same direction as was done in the inboard aiming hole, but make sure you finish in the clockwise screwdriver direction. If you are adjusting in the counterclockwise screwdriver direction, overshoot the adjustment by one full turn and then turn it clockwise one full turn, so you finish the adjustment in the clockwise direction and still line up with the vertical aiming line. Do NOT turn this outboard screw in a different direction or a different amount than was done with the inboard aiming screw.
